result.title: Day 4 Analysis
result.content:
Problem A. Game

The strategy for both players is to throw away only one ball per turn.

So the player who have higher number of balls should win, and if they have equal number of balls, then the second player should win.

Code: 11708530

Problem B. Coder

Put the items in the same manner we discussed before in problem DZY loves chess board.

Code: 11708590

Problem C. Jeff and Digits

For a number to be divisible by 90, it has to be divisible by 10 and divisible by 9.

For it to be divisible by 10, the last digit has to be zero.

And for it to be divisible by 9, the sum of the digits in the number has to be divisible by 9.

So to make the maximum number, we should put all the cars with the number 5 to the left and all the cards with the number 0 to the right, and then keep removing cards from left till the sum of digits is divisible by 9.

Code: 11708785

Problem D. Prison Transfer

This problem needs some clever implementation.

First of all we have n â€” c + 1 segments that we need to check.

If we loop on the items of every segment, this will be too much processing with complexity O(n^2), which will obviously time out.

Luckily, there is huge intersection between every two neighbouring segments as they just differ in only one prisoner.

We can make use of this fact and reduce the complexity of the solution.

Let's think of the segments moving like this sliding window.


-----------------------------------------------------------------
|          |                                                    
-----------------------------------------------------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------
  |          |                                                  -----------------------------------------------------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------
    |          |                                                
-----------------------------------------------------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------
      |          |                                              
-----------------------------------------------------------------

So we can just check the first segment and then deduce the next segment by just discarding the left most prisoner and including one new prisoner in the segment to the right.

So the total complexity will be O(n)

Code: 11708922

Problem E. Hungry Sequence

An important observation to make for this problem is that a sorted sequence of prime numbers is considered as a hungry sequence.

So we can just generate the first n prime numbers and sort them.

Since n can be large up to 10^5, the trivial algorithm for generating the prime numbers will not fit in time.

For fast generation of prime numbers, you can refer to Sieve of Eratosthenes, which is a fast algorithm for generating the prime numbers up to a given limit.

So you can generate the primes up to certain limit (large enough to be sure that you'll find n primes below it).

And then output the first n primes.

Code: 11710619

Problem F. Design Tutorial: Make It Nondeterministic

A greedy algorithm should work for this problem.

the first person in the given permutation should pick the lexicographically smaller name for his handle, such that it is not smaller than the previous person.

Code: 11710769
